channel.title: Brandon Boswell
channel.description: Recent content from Brandon Boswell's Digital Garden

item.title: Video Editing Tips from Watching Keep Productive
item.description: He flashes his branding at the beginning of the video instead of breaking it up and then jumps directly into the intro His B-Roll is heavily zoomed it and uses plenty of scrolling animation It seems like much of his scrolling is added in post-production Uses more Zoom in than scrolling, this is less jarring.
item.content:encoded:
• He flashes his branding at the beginning of the video instead of breaking it up and then jumps directly into the intro
  • His B-Roll is heavily zoomed it and uses plenty of scrolling animation
  • It seems like much of his scrolling is added in post-production
  • Uses more Zoom in than scrolling, this is less jarring.
  • Has a title at the beginning of each section
    • For any hard-cut editing he will use a zoom cut to make it feel less jarring.
  • Francesco makes very good eye contact with the camera throughout.
  • Side-by-Side recap at the end
    • Didn’t ask for the like at the end (this could simplify the outro)
    • Subscribe Call To Action at the End
      • Put hashtags in the description to be included. Ex: # productivity

item.title: Five Novelty Categories
item.description: People read nonfiction to learn and to feel. My framework for ensuring a blog post accomplishes both is to start with a first draft that focuses on “novel” ideas. A novel idea is one that’s not just new to the reader, but also significant and not easily intuited.
item.content:encoded:
People read nonfiction to learn and to feel. My framework for ensuring a blog post accomplishes both is to start with a first draft that focuses on “novel” ideas. A novel idea is one that’s not just new to the reader, but also significant and not easily intuited. Think of it as new and worthwhile

Julian mentions there are five novelty categories:

  • Counter-intuitive — “Oh, I never realized the world worked that way.”
  • Counter-narrative — “Wow, that’s not how I was told the world worked!”
  • Shock and awe — “That’s crazy. I would have never believed it.”
  • Elegant articulations — “Beautiful. I couldn’t have said it better myself.”
  • Make someone feel seen — “Yes! That’s exactly how I feel!”

item.title: Reasons to Write
item.description: We write to: clear our minds reflect on our experiences force ourselves to dive deeper satisfy our curiosities teach others build reputation hone our craft Source: Julian Shapiro
item.content:encoded:
We write to:

  • clear our minds
  • reflect on our experiences
  • force ourselves to dive deeper
  • satisfy our curiosities
  • teach others
  • build reputation
  • hone our craft

Source: Julian Shapiro

item.title: Be generous with your time and connections to create bonds
item.description: I need to be mindful of this and slow down when meeting with teammate. My natural pace is very quick, but I need to make sure they know that I care about them and have the time for them.
item.content:encoded: I need to be mindful of this and slow down when meeting with teammate. My natural pace is very quick, but I need to make sure they know that I care about them and have the time for them.

item.title: No author can generate profound insights on a fixed schedule
item.description: This is part of why I shoot for a video every two weeks, but if I don’t have anything to say then it is not worth posting.
item.content:encoded: This is part of why I shoot for a video every two weeks, but if I don’t have anything to say then it is not worth posting.

item.content:encoded: Who moved my cheese?

item.title: Spaced Repetition for your tasks
item.description: Achieve inbox zero for your tasks each day. Not by doing more, but by using the mechanism of spaced repetition in a different way. Here we’re not trying to remember things.
item.content:encoded:
Achieve inbox zero for your tasks each day. Not by doing more, but by using the mechanism of spaced repetition in a different way. Here we’re not trying to remember things. We’re actually trying to do the exact opposite. We’re going to be reminded of tasks in increasingly longer intervals until we eventually decide to do the task or archive it.

  • When I see a task in the inbox (usually each morning) I will decide if this something that I need to do this week?

    • If so and there is room for it, then great.

  • If it doesn’t need to be done this week, when should I think about it again?

    • I do weekly reflection and planning on Sunday, so my default answer is often then.

    • If I’m not ready to do it, or I’m not sure it’s worth doing, I might schedule it from 2 Sundays from now.

    • If it’s even less important than that then let’s go 4 weeks out.

    • If it goes much more than that then I we might as well throw it in the Someday bucket or archive it.

    • Similarly, if I have snoozed a task more than a couple of times, that is usually an indicator that there is something off about this task. Either it’s not important, I don’t understand it, or I’m scared of it.

item.title: Seeing everything on your plate can be overwhelming
item.description: You don’t need to and shouldn’t need to see task counts. This isn’t a quantitative scenario. Seeing everything is just going to overwhelm you. Instead, let’s focus on what we need to do today.
item.content:encoded: You don’t need to and shouldn’t need to see task counts. This isn’t a quantitative scenario. Seeing everything is just going to overwhelm you. Instead, let’s focus on what we need to do today.

item.title: Inbox Zero
item.description: Apps where I subscribe to Inbox Zero Gmail Reader Akiflow
item.content:encoded:
Apps where I subscribe to Inbox Zero

  • Gmail
  • Reader
  • Akiflow

item.title: Stop playing with your tasks
item.description: In TickTick I had a bunch of lists and every time something came into the Inbox I had to put it into a list to get it out of the inbox.
item.content:encoded:
In TickTick I had a bunch of lists and every time something came into the Inbox I had to put it into a list to get it out of the inbox. That doesn’t sound like a lot of work, but now I have to decide what category to put it into. It’s a bunch of unnecessary decisions that feels like I’m playing with my tasks instead of doing my tasks. In Akiflow the inbox is based on when you intend to do the work vs is it in a list. Now I look at the task, think about when I should do it or consider doing it and move on.

Less Metadata, more prioritization.

item.title: Managing tasks should be fast and frictionless
item.description: Stop playing with your tasks
item.content:encoded: Stop playing with your tasks

item.title: Snoozing
item.description: Snoozing the Inbox lets me create distance between me and the idea or task so that I can better evaluate if it’s worth my time. “The real measure of any time management technique is whether it helps you to neglect the right things so that you can focus on what matters most“
item.content:encoded:
Snoozing the Inbox lets me create distance between me and the idea or task so that I can better evaluate if it’s worth my time.

“The real measure of any time management technique is whether it helps you to neglect the right things so that you can focus on what matters most“

item.title: Distance is important for clarity
item.description: Snoozing is nice to have as it allows to you create space from the task to evaluate it.
item.content:encoded: Snoozing is nice to have as it allows to you create space from the task to evaluate it.

item.title: Don’t do everything
item.description: Unless a task is urgent, it is helpful to have some time away from the idea to evaluate whether it is truly as important as it felt when capturing it. Often times the answer is no.
item.content:encoded:
Unless a task is urgent, it is helpful to have some time away from the idea to evaluate whether it is truly as important as it felt when capturing it. Often times the answer is no.

Distance is important for clarity

item.title: Daily Highlight
item.description: Something that if accomplished would make today a success. I also sometimes refer to this as “ Progress Time“. This is the time when you make progress on something meaningful.
item.content:encoded:
Something that if accomplished would make today a success.

I also sometimes refer to this as “ Progress Time“. This is the time when you make progress on something meaningful.

item.title: $10K Work
item.description: Setting a Daily Highlight is one of the best ways to make sure you prioritize High Leverage work
item.content:encoded: Setting a Daily Highlight is one of the best ways to make sure you prioritize High Leverage work

item.title: Choose the right mix of the things
item.description: Not everything you do today is going to be million dollar work, but you don’t want to only do 2 minute rule tasks exclusively either. Low Leverage Tasks $10K Work
item.content:encoded:
Not everything you do today is going to be million dollar work, but you don’t want to only do 2 minute rule tasks exclusively either. Low Leverage Tasks

item.title: Swift Development
item.description: Let me start by saying, I am not a Swift developer. These are just some of the resources I stumbled upon when grokking my way through Swift development https://github.
item.content:encoded:
Let me start by saying, I am not a Swift developer. These are just some of the resources I stumbled upon when grokking my way through Swift development

https://github.com/sindresorhus/LaunchAtLogin https://www.raywenderlich.com/28684964-swiftui-layout-interfaces https://www.raywenderlich.com/28684524-swiftui-fundamentals https://www.raywenderlich.com/19165608-integrating-uikit-swiftui https://www.raywenderlich.com/4001741-swiftui https://github.com/sindresorhus/Preferences https://www.raywenderlich.com/28797163-your-first-ios-swiftui-app-an-app-from-scratch https://www.raywenderlich.com/28092971-programming-in-swift-fundamentals

item.title: Coaching
item.description: Coaching is not the same thing as giving advice. Coaching is strategic advice giving. It’s about helping people improve their thinking—not solving problems for them.
item.content:encoded: Coaching is not the same thing as giving advice. Coaching is strategic advice giving. It’s about helping people improve their thinking—not solving problems for them.
